Postage.-We notice that an order has passed
the Legislature ofPennsyl for the postage in
cured by Members during The Session to be paid
out OF the Treasury. A similar order has passed
The House OF Delegates Of Maryland, which. 10 our
minds, seems perfectly right. The public have
but little idea how burthcnsome this has become 10
the members-many OF them receive fifteen or
twenty letters almost daily on the public account,
which often amount TO more than half their per d.
en-. Such things are quite oppressive and ought not
to be borne. Public servants are subject to many
impositions, and We know Of none more erievous


than to have to attend 10 the onerous business Of
those who lack the good breeding to pay postage
when asking favor for themselves. .--Batt Patriot.

occurrence which took place on "Wednesday NOR.

has been extreme, though somewhat aha;ed since

PHILADELPHIA Press.

A recent traveller in The British Colony Of the
Cape of Good Hope, relates the following incident.


Having learned that there was to be sale oil
cattle. farm stock, sc. by auction. at Weld Cor
nets in the vicinity, we halted our Wagon one day
for the purpose OF procuring fresh span OF oxen.
Among the stock Of the farm sold, vas female
slave and three children. The two eldest child en-
were girls the one ebout thirteen years ot age, and
the other about eleven the youngest was boy.
The whole family were examined together, but they
were sold separately, and to different purchasers
The farmers examined them as if they had been so
many head of cattle. While the sale was going on,
the mother and children were exhibited on table,
that they might be seen by the company, which was
very large. There could not have been a finer sub
ject for On able painter than this uohsppy grouPe.
The tears, the anguish Of the mother, while she
met The gaze of the multitude, eyed the different
countcnance OF the bidders. or cast heart rendlng
look upon the children, and the simplicity and The
touching sorrow OF the poor young ones, while they
cung their distracted parent, wiplng their eyes.
and half ealing their faces-contrased with The
marked sibty and ocular countenances Of tn e
spectators and purchasets,-furnished a striking
commentary on the miscries OF slavery, and It's de
basng effects upon the hearts oil its abetors While
the woman was in this distressed situation she was
asked, Can you feed sheepf' Her reply was so
indistnct tha, il escaped me; but it was probably
IN thc negative, LOT hcr purchaser FeJ"h'su ~ ouu
and harsh voice" Then will teach you with a
rhinoceros hide The mother and her three chit
dren sold to three separate purchasers, and
they were, literally tern from each other"

Washington, Jan 27-We are sorry to hear,
from Georgia, that there is more trouble on the
frontiers The surveyors Of the State Of Georgia,
in attempting to run off the lines Of the land West
ward Of the New Treaty Line, and East of the
Georgia COMMISSIONER Line. have been stopped
in their course by depuation Of Indian Chiefs
from the Little Prince. The Indians, it is said,
exhibited TO the Surveyors plot Of that section ol
country, with the New Treaty Lines marked there
on and protested against the right Of Georgia to
cross it, for the pu pose Of surveying the territory,
which, they maintained yet belonged to the Indians
We hope the Indians will be satisfied with protest.
ing. Iatelligencer.

General Washington's WOrh's.--It is with great
satisfaction we have learnt, that MIR. Jared SPARKS.
Editor Of the North American Review, has made
arrangements with Judge Washington for publish
ing an entire edition of " General Washington's
Works." to consist OF his letters to the Governor
Of Virginia during the French war, his Stale Pa
pers, Official Correspondence, both military and ci
vii, and such Of his private letters may be deem
ed suited for publication the whole to be compris
ed in series oil volumes. with notes and iilustra
tions by the esteemed editor. II is we'll known.
that Gen. Washington preserved, with scrupulous
care, copies of his own letters, as we'll the pro
digious number OF originals which he received
from other persons. In addition to the ul use oil
these papers, which are now at Mount Vernon, MIR
Sparks will prof. by a mass o materials Tor Re
volu,ionary History, which has been gathered by a
personal inspection Of the several public Offices in the
old States. as well as from various private sources
The records. correspondence, and other papers Of
the old Congress. are preserved in the Department
Of State, to which he will also have


With these advantages and resources in aid Of the
editor, it may be expected that the work will pos
sess national interest, and constitute most vaua
bic addition 10 our political history. We understand
that Chief Justice Marshall cordially approves the
plan, and will contribute such facilities may be In
his power 10 promote its sexecu,ion.--sNat, latel.

OF the scrding OF troops to Portugal, with Mr. Can.
ning's speech, &C. had just reached Paris, and the
public were awaiting with great solicilude TO see
what course the French government would adopt.


The party in France called the Congregation, arc
considered as going hand in hand with the ultra
patty in Spain being inclined TO war with England,
and having hopes Of exciting diversion in ireland.

In the Senate, en- Friday, the Committee to whom
had been referred the joint Resolution, pedging ,hs
vote of Pennsylvania to General Jackson in 1899.
reported that nex peden, for ,heIegisalure to
bring the name Of Andrew Jackson before the Pco

OF the subject. A second reading OF the Resolution

motion was sustained, and the report was laid on

philadelphia Press.

Postage.-We notice that an order has passed
the Legislature ofPennsyl for the postage in
cured by Members during The Session to be paid
out OF the Treasury. A similar order has passed
The House OF Delegates Of Maryland, which. 10 our
minds, seems perfectly right. The public have
but little idea how burthcnsome this has become 10
the members-many OF them receive fifteen or
twenty letters almost daily on the public account,
which often amount TO more than half their per d.
en-. Such things are quite oppressive and ought not
to be borne. Public servants are subject to many
impositions, and We know Of none more erievous


than to have to attend 10 the onerous business Of
those who lack the good breeding to pay postage
when asking favor for themselves. .--Batt Patriot.

A meeting has recently been held in this city for


he purpose Of organising society here TO promote


Missions to foreign parts at which, as usual, much


(mphasi. was laid the presence, speeches and


ate ments, Of such among the assembly as had


cen occupied 10, or Witnessed the effects Of these


binistraiions in distant lands.


II is The furthest thing in the world from our
kurpose 10 question the benevolent motives or con


uc. of the latter pei sons, oI those who, stmua


Id by their zeal and representations, seek TO turn


n such a channel, the liberal charities Of our
we must in all Difference be permitted
~ question the discretion, and the expedency OF
Rhe attempt itself The suggestions on this subject


,he annexed communication from much res


ec,ed friend, are entitled TO deep attention. and We
Khall perhaps be excused Tor ampliynY little on
lhe same topics


There is most undoubtedly enough Of vice. and


ignorance, and destitution Of religious instruction in
Eur land. nay in our own city, where there pro-
badly thousands in state Of mental and spiritual


chase ment, hardly less than that ol the lindoos
Band wich isanders-to give occupation aud scope


or all that individual charity can hope TO accom-
Blish. US then turn our eyes and our efforts


Inward - Let the darkness Of our own communities
be made light, before we 90 forth into far distant


ands to disseminate the truths OF which many at


home are uniformed. II is true thai in visiting
Ind in comforting the miserable novels which in q





misery and more oa,hsome vices of that portion OF


he population, to which we have referred. as need
ng religious instruction. there is OF the thea.
&ical effect nothing Of the perilous and therefore
ATTRACTIVE adventure, nothing of the spirit, and per
haps almost hope, Of possible martyrdom. which
belong to the preparation and DEPARTURE aud labors
II missionaries TO foreign parts There is solemn


cave taking among friends, no swelling anthems of
|prayer and praise, as the faed minister is commit
,k. unc upb .pI and 4 /.
hangers. which affection magnifes ,enlod, of
known lands and unknown races Of men-no public


meetings. eloquent appeals, no lavdatory resolu
Hons, to be published in the newspapers But there
lis, therefore, The more need that every proper in
.ducement should BE- held out to the encouragement
|ot that more humble and ncomparably more useful
domestic mnislration above alluded to; and we
Should therefore, hesitate to divert from this source
la single contribution. With these remarks, made
|cer,sinly without any other motive than tina, ot the
common good, we submit the communication refer
red 10.


III the Editor Of the ". T. american.
Every cousideratc person mus, regret the well
meant, but i'll directed zeal which is displayed for
Foreign missions. Docs not our own country The
population of which spreads far beyond the provs-
ions that exist for its religious and moral instruction
afford ample scope for all the display OF Chris ian
z=al and pious liberslity The Heather in foreign
counties do not need as much many portions Of
our country, the lsbours of missionaries. They
taken care of by nation whose funds ample for
This purpose, and who have not the need as
I've have for these funds at home. Great Britain by
her various missionary institutions. her society for
the promotion Of Christian knowledge, Church
Missionary Society, London Missionary Society,
&c. SC. i. extending the benefits o Christianity to
Heather nations. A Church establishment in India
with College at Calcutta, and Baptist Seminary
and missionaries provide for the wants of that coun
Try. 1t is understood tina, at Ccylon the British
authorities have intima,ed wish that no more
American missionaries be sent there, and have re-
fused to sanction proposed College, alleging very
properly that they are competent TO provide for the
religious instruction Of the people IN their own do
minons. Our duty evidently is to take cafe OF the
extending population of our own country who are
destitute Of the ordinances Of the gospel. and
circumstances admit, of the unfortunate Indians,
whom We have displaced from the soil Of their
fathers. \.

A recent traveller in The British Colony Of the
Cape of Good Hope, relates the following incident.


Having learned that there was to be sale oil
cattle. farm stock, sc. by auction. at Weld Cor
nets in the vicinity, we halted our Wagon one day
for the purpose OF procuring fresh span OF oxen.
Among the stock Of the farm sold, vas female
slave and three children. The two eldest child en-
were girls the one ebout thirteen years ot age, and
the other about eleven the youngest was boy.
The whole family were examined together, but they
were sold separately, and to different purchasers
The farmers examined them as if they had been so
many head of cattle. While the sale was going on,
the mother and children were exhibited on table,
that they might be seen by the company, which was
very large. There could not have been a finer sub
ject for On able painter than this uohsppy grouPe.
The tears, the anguish Of the mother, while she
met The gaze of the multitude, eyed the different
countcnance OF the bidders. or cast heart rendlng
look upon the children, and the simplicity and The
touching sorrow OF the poor young ones, while they
cung their distracted parent, wiplng their eyes.
and half ealing their faces-contrased with The
marked sibty and ocular countenances Of tn e
spectators and purchasets,-furnished a striking
commentary on the miscries OF slavery, and It's de
basng effects upon the hearts oil its abetors While
the woman was in this distressed situation she was
asked, Can you feed sheepf' Her reply was so
indistnct tha, il escaped me; but it was probably
IN thc negative, LOT hcr purchaser FeJ"h'su ~ ouu
and harsh voice" Then will teach you with a
rhinoceros hide The mother and her three chit
dren sold to three separate purchasers, and
they were, literally tern from each other"


yfrtful question.-D Dominica, the harlequin, go
ing 10 see Louis XIV at supper, fixed his eye on a
dish Of partridges. The king. who was fond Of his
acting. said, "give tha, dish 10 Dominica" "And
the par,rdges foo, Site,' Louis penetrating bis
art, replied, and the cartridges too The dish
0as gold.

Washington, Jan 27-We are sorry to hear,
from Georgia, that there is more trouble on the
frontiers The surveyors Of the State Of Georgia,
in attempting to run off the lines Of the land West
ward Of the New Treaty Line, and East of the
Georgia COMMISSIONER Line. have been stopped
in their course by depuation Of Indian Chiefs
from the Little Prince. The Indians, it is said,
exhibited TO the Surveyors plot Of that section ol
country, with the New Treaty Lines marked there
on and protested against the right Of Georgia to
cross it, for the pu pose Of surveying the territory,
which, they maintained yet belonged to the Indians
We hope the Indians will be satisfied with protest.
ing. Iatelligencer.

General Washington's WOrh's.--It is with great
satisfaction we have learnt, that MIR. Jared SPARKS.
Editor Of the North American Review, has made
arrangements with Judge Washington for publish
ing an entire edition of " General Washington's
Works." to consist OF his letters to the Governor
Of Virginia during the French war, his Stale Pa
pers, Official Correspondence, both military and ci
vii, and such Of his private letters may be deem
ed suited for publication the whole to be compris
ed in series oil volumes. with notes and iilustra
tions by the esteemed editor. II is we'll known.
that Gen. Washington preserved, with scrupulous
care, copies of his own letters, as we'll the pro
digious number OF originals which he received
from other persons. In addition to the ul use oil
these papers, which are now at Mount Vernon, MIR
Sparks will prof. by a mass o materials Tor Re
volu,ionary History, which has been gathered by a
personal inspection Of the several public Offices in the
old States. as well as from various private sources
The records. correspondence, and other papers Of
the old Congress. are preserved in the Department
Of State, to which he will also have


With these advantages and resources in aid Of the
editor, it may be expected that the work will pos
sess national interest, and constitute most vaua
bic addition 10 our political history. We understand
that Chief Justice Marshall cordially approves the
plan, and will contribute such facilities may be In
his power 10 promote its sexecu,ion.--sNat, latel.
